body.section:
Updating the Keystone Identity Service
This topic explains configuration options for the Identity Service. allows you to perform updates on the following parts of the Identity service configuration:

ul.li: Any content in main keystone configuration file: /etc/keystone/keystone.conf. This allows to manipulate Keystone configuration parameters. Please refer to the Updating the main Identity Service configuration file section next.

Updating certain configuration options and enabling features, such as:
Verbosity of logs being written to keystone log files.
Process counts for Apache2 WSGI module, separately for admin and public Keystone interfaces
Enabling/disabling auditing.
Enabling/disabling Fernet Tokens.
Please refer to Enabling Keystone Features section below.

Creating and updating domain-specific configuration files: /etc/keystone/domains/keystone.<domain_name>.conf. This allows to integrate Keystone with one or more external authentication sources, such as LDAP server. Please refer to Integrating with an external LDAP server section below.

section.title: Updating the main Identity Service configuration file

ol.li:
The main Keystone Identity Service configuration file (/etc/keystone/keystone.conf), located on each control plane server is generated from the following template file located on a lifecycle manager: /home/stack/helion/my_cloud/config/keystone/keystone.conf.j2
Modify this template file as appropriate. Please refer to Keystone Liberty documentation for full descriptions of all settings: This is a Jinja2 template, which expects certain template variables to be set. Do not change values inside double curly braces: {{ }}.
has the token expiration setting as below, which is different from the upstream value "3600": [token] expiration = 14400

Once the template is modified, commit the change to the local git repository, and rerun the configuration processor / deployment area preparation playbooks (as suggested at Using Git for Configuration Management): $ cd ~/helion $ git checkout site $ git add my_cloud/config/keystone/keystone.conf.j2 $ git commit -m "Adjusting some parameters in keystone.conf" $ cd ~/helion/hos/ansible $ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml $ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Run reconfiguration playbook in deployment area: $ cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible $ ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts keystone-reconfigure.yml

body.section:
Enabling Identity Service features To enable or disable Keystone features like Fernet Tokens, do the following:
Adjust respective parameters in /home/stack/helion/my_cloud/config/keystone/keystone_deploy_config.yml.
Commit the change into local git repository, and rerun configuration processor / deployment area preparation playbooks (as suggested at Using Git for Configuration Management): $ cd ~/helion $ git checkout site $ git add my_cloud/config/keystone/keystone_deploy_config.yml $ git commit -m "Adjusting some WSGI or logging parameters for keystone" $ cd ~/helion/hos/ansible $ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml $ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Run reconfiguration playbook in deployment area: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible $ ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts keystone-reconfigure.yml

section.title: Fernet Token
section.p: supports UUID tokens by default. Fernet Tokens are available as an experimental feature. You can switch to using Fernet tokens instead of UUID tokens by following the above steps. The benefit of using Fernet tokens is that tokens are not persisted in a database, which is helpful if you want to deploy Keystone Identity service as one master and multiple slaves: only roles, projects, etc. will need to be replicated from master to slaves, not the token table. The tradeoff is the cost of token validation. According to our performance testing, although Fernet tokens perform slightly better than UUID on token creation, the degradation is about 400% on token validation when compared to UUID tokens. The performance degradation is caused mainly by database operations; there are 39 queries per fernet token validation, while UUID causes only 2 queries per token validation.
section.note: Tempest doesn't work with Fernet Tokens in . If Fernet tokens are enabled, please don't run token tests in Tempest.

During reconfiguration when switching to a Fernet token provider or during Fernet key rotation, you may see a warning in keystone.log stating "[fernet_tokens] key_repository is world readable: /etc/keystone/fernet-keys/". This is expected. You can safely ignore the message. For other Keystone operations, you won't see this warning. The directory permissions are actually set to 600 (read/write by owner only), not world readable.
